body: Ignoring the frames may be most appropriate. I think this broke several years ago when old streams became no longer retained.

I've seen the log entries described in https://github.com/grpc/grpc-java/issues/3548 as well. The race condition is intrinsic to the protocol: there is no way for a peer to send a RST and ensure that there are not DATA (or other frames) already in flight. The docs at the origin of the exception [here](https://github.com/netty/netty/blob/4.1/codec-http2/src/main/java/io/netty/handler/codec/http2/DefaultHttp2ConnectionDecoder.java#L532) even describe the situation. 

I think the behavior we have now is about as good as we can hope for other than we shouldn't pollute logs with it, at least at info or higher levels. Sending a RST in response to these frames is probably smart to combat bad behavior of peers, though the spec does say the frames should be ignored.

There is one way we could do a little better, but it's slightly complex. We can hubristically tell if the frame is the start of a new stream by the fact that DATA frames will never initiate a stream and trailer HEADERS frames won't contain any pseudo headers. If we do that, we can presume any HEADERS that are not trailers are an out-of-order new stream and we can elevate the exception to a connection level PROTOCOL_ERROR as described in the [spec](https://http2.github.io/http2-spec/#rfc.section.5.1.1/). Trailer headers and DATA frames can then be presumed to belong to a stream that was RST, and ignored. The drawback is that this doesn't protect against peers that are sending orphan DATA of trailer HEADERS frames, but ignoring them is probably not much worse than sending a RST since this is kind of worst-case peer behavior.

@bryce-anderson this isn't necessarily a bad remote peer–they might not have received the RST before sending the DATA frame, so I think we should just ignore them.  telling the difference between a bad-actor remote peer and an honest-mistake remote peer seems too hard.

Looking at the spec in the stream state section (§5.1), for "closed" it says:
> Endpoints MUST ignore WINDOW_UPDATE or RST_STREAM frames received in this state, though endpoints MAY choose to treat frames that arrive a significant time after sending END_STREAM as a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR.

Let's ignore it, and maybe log at debug. Info isn't great to log at because it is on by default.

Earlier we tried to support the "may" by remembering old streams, but it was too memory intensive/painful and thrown away.

@mosesn, it's not even necessarily an 'honest mistake', there is no way to prevent the race.

Ignoring the messages is fine outside of the case where the peer tries to initiate an out-of-order stream. In that case ignoring the frame may cause the peer to hang unless they decide to reset the illegal stream themselves. From the perspective of _this_ session, it's probably still fine to ignore this case since the alternative is to tear down the session as described in section (§5.1.1):

> The identifier of a newly established stream MUST be numerically greater than all streams that the initiating endpoint has opened or reserved. This governs streams that are opened using a HEADERS frame and streams that are reserved using PUSH_PROMISE. An endpoint that receives an unexpected stream identifier MUST respond with a connection error (Section 5.4.1) of type PROTOCOL_ERROR.

That said, it's not terribly difficult to see if the headers are stream initiating headers vs trailers potentially from a reset stream: just check for pseudo headers.
Thanks for the input guys! I'm working on a testing a potential fix and will open a PR soon.

@normanmaurer, assuming I get a PR accepted for this issue would it be possible to do a release of Netty early next week to get it incorporated? We are trying to get this issue fixed for a new product launch.

issue.title: Issue #8025. Ignoring HEADER and DATA frames for streams that may hav…

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
…e existed in the past.

Motivation:

Correctly ignore frames that come in after a RST_STREAM is sent.

Modification:

Ignoring frames that are for a stream that may have existed in the past instead of throwing an exception.

Result:

Fixes #8025.

body: @shorea yep... sounds good. We wanted to do a Netty release anyway :)
